title: Analysis of N-glycans from Raphanus sativus Cultivars Using PNGase H+
procedures:
1. Sample collection
Purchase different cultivars of fresh radish (Raphanus sativus L.).
2. Isolation of Protein from Radish
Homogenize approximately 100 g of fresh radish with a kitchen blender for 10 min.
Transfer the slurry to a 50 mL centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 14,000 × g at 4 °C for 20 min to remove the insoluble material.
Transfer the supernatant carefully into a new 50 mL centrifuge tube and add an equal volume of 2 M trichloroacetic acid (TCA) solution.
	NOTE: Adding TCA will precipitate soluble (glyco)proteins.
Centrifuge at 14,000 × g at 4 °C for 30 min and remove the supernatant from the pelleted (glyco) proteins.
Wash the pellet with 20 mL of deionized water and centrifuge at 14,000 × g at 4 °C for 5 min to remove soluble oligosaccharides and polysaccharides.
Repeat step 2.5. four times.
Re-suspend the pellets in 1 mL of deionized water and transfer to a fresh 1.5 mL centrifuge tube.
3. Preparation of N-Glycans
Mix 50 µL of protein solution from step 2.7. (equal to 5 g of fresh radish) with 0.2 mU of recombinant PNGase H+ in 10 mM acetic acid.
Incubate the reaction mixture at 37 °C for 12 h. After the incubation, centrifuge at 14,000 × g for 5 min to remove the extra protein and enzyme.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 1.5 mL centrifuge tube.
4. Purification of N-Glycans
Prepare the solid-phase extraction (SPE) column to enrich the N-glycans and remove salts and other impurities from the reaction mixture, increasing the selectivity of the fluorogenic 2-aminobenzamide (2-AB) labeling agent for N-glycan derivatization.
	
Add 3 mL of deionized water to wash the column.
Add 3 mL of 80% acetonitrile solution containing trifluoroacetic acid (TFA, 0.1% v/v) to active the SPE-column.

Add 3 mL of deionized water to equilibrate the SPE-column.
Transfer the sample from step 3.3 onto the column and discard the flow-through.
Add 1.5 mL of deionized water to wash the column and discard the flow-through.
Elute the released N-glycans from the column using 1.5 mL of aqueous 20% acetonitrile solution, containing 0.1% TFA (v/v) into a 2 mL centrifuge tube.
Remove the solvent by centrifugal evaporation at room temperature. Evaporate until the sample is completely dry.
5. Fluorescence Derivatization of N-Glycans
Prepare 1 mL of 2-AB solution, consisting of 35 mM 2-AB and 0.1 M sodium cyanoborohydride in dimethyl sulfoxide/acetic acid solution (7:3, v/v).
Add 5 µL of 2-AB solution to the dried samples (step 4.5.) derived from six different radishes. Vortex each sample until completely dissolved.
Incubate the mixture for 2 h at 65 °C.
Let the sample cool down to room temperature for 5 min, and add 5 µL of deionized water and 40 µL of acetonitrile. Centrifuge the tubes at 14,000 x g for 3 min.
Transfer 48 µL from the supernatant into a 300 µL high-recovery HPLC vial. Store the derivatized N-glycan samples at -20 °C for up to one month.
6. HILIC-UPLC profiling of N-glycans
Analyze the samples using a standard UPLC system connected to an online fluorescence detectorset at the excitation/emission wavelengths of 330 nm/420 nm, respectively.
Use a hydrophobic interaction liquid chromatography (HILIC)-UPLC glycan column at a column temperature of 60 °C for the analysis.
Prepare solvent A by diluting 50 mL of stock solution (1 M ammonium formate solution, pH 4.5) with 950 mL of liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LCMS)-grade water. Prepare the stock solution as follows:
	
Add 43 mL of formic acid to 700 mL of LCMS-grade H2O.

Adjust the pH to 4.5 by dropwise addition of aqueous ammonia solution (25% w/w).
Transfer the solvent to a measuring cylinder and fill up to 1000 mL with LCMS-grade H2O. Store at 4-6 °C for up to 3 months.
Use LCMS-grade acetonitrile as solvent B.
Separate N-glycans with the following gradient elution:
	
Start by adding 95% of solvent B into solvent A. Set the flow rate at 0.5 mL/min from 0 to 44.5 min.
From 0 min to 6 min, gradually decrease the proportion of solvent B with a linear gradient to78%.
From 6 min to 44.5 min, gradually decrease the proportion of solvent B with a linear gradient to 55.9%.
From 44.5 min to 46.5 min, rapidly decrease the proportion of solvent B with a linear gradient from 55.9% to 0% and hold at 0% for 2 min, and initiate washing of the column. Reduce the flow rate to 0.25 mL/min from 44.5 to 55 min.
Wash the column further by increasing solvent B to 95% from 48.5 min to 50.5 min and hold at 95% for 4.5 min.
Re-equilibrate the column to the starting conditions of 95% solvent B at 0.5 mL/min from 50.5 to 57 min.
Inject 45 µL of the sample into the UPLC system.
Elute the N-glycans by UPLC with retention times between 15 and 40 min.
Collect each observed UPLC peak fraction using 2 mL centrifuge tubes and dry the samples by centrifugal evaporation.
Inject approximately 1 pmol of 2-AB labeled dextran standard (2−20 glucose units) to calibrate the plant-N-glycan profiling, and to assign their elution times into standardized glucose units.
7. MALDI-TOF MS Analysis

Dissolve the samples from step 6.8 in 5 µL of LCMS -grade water. Mix 1 µL of the sample solution and 1 µL of 6-aza-2-thiothymine (ATT) solution (0.3% w/v in 70% v/v aqueous acetonitrile), and pipette the mixture onto the MALDI-TOF sample carrier.
Analyze the samples using a MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer instrument in positive ion mode by pressing the Start button.
Analyze the mass spectra by using the accompanying MALDI-TOF-MS analysis software.
Interpret the spectra using an open source glycan interpretation software19. Set the search parameters for 2-AB labeling, [M+Na]+, and set the accuracy parameter to 2.0 Da.
